comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Hi Beachcomber, the white paintwork as a permanent feature was introduced with the 'Strath' liners of the 1930s (hence their nickname the 'White Sisters') instead of the traditional black hull and stone-coloured upperworks. P&O had used the white colour scheme only twice before - briefly with CALEDONIA in the mid 1890s and with SALSETTE on the tropical Aden-Bombay route around 1910. An article on the launch of STRATHAIRD in 1931 mentions the new colour scheme. It was meant to signify the company's new direction, and (getting technical here) 'a degree of energy, speed and beauty never before attempted'!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/35317829@N06] Hi Phil, I think you are right re the heat! The article in the response above mentions that the new white colour scheme of the 1930s produced lower temperatures onboard... phew... Interesting side note, apparently MONGOLIA's sister ship MOLDAVIA was fitted with a dummy second funnel in 1928 to 'provide a more impressive profile' - however it only exaggerated the vessel's top-heaviness so was thankfully not applied to MONGOLIA. It's all about the aesthetics!
